title: Cinematographer Bradford Young Creates a ‘Healing’ Work of Art
text:
Cinematographer Bradford Young is a rising star in Hollywood, having been Oscar-nominated for the 2016 sci-fi film, “Arrival,” and praised for his camera work on 2014’s “Selma” and the recent Netflix series, “When They See Us.” The 42-year-old Louisville, Ky., native also is becoming a fixture in the art scene, with friends like architect David Adjaye and a buzzy project opening in Philadelphia next month.

“Sometimes I want my lens to have an opinion,” Mr. Young said. “With films, I need to shut up and point the camera, but the art world is more intuitive. Art can handle my questions about blackness. I can have a soapbox if I want it.”

His multi-screen installation, “Back and Song,” will be unveiled Oct. 5 in the soaring stone chapel of Girard College, a Philadelphia boarding school. The project, a commission of the art organization Philadelphia Contemporary and Thomas Jefferson University, subtly nods to the history of U.S. medical schools and hospitals treating—and mistreating—black patients.

The chapel at Girard College, a Philadelphia boarding school, is where the ‘Back and Song’ multi-screen installation will be displayed. Photo: Girard College

Mr. Young and a collaborating artist, Elissa Blount Moorhead, have been layering archival footage of traditional black healers with recent clips of black cultural leaders to illustrate the cathartic ways black communities seek healing on their own terms.

Mr. Young said he was motivated to explore the issue after reading a 2016 study by University of Virginia researchers that detailed the troubling reasons why black people are often under-treated for pain. (In the study of 222 white medical students and residents around the country, 40% of the students and 25% of the residents told researchers they thought black people’s skin was thicker than that of white people.) After mulling the sad statistics and conferring with his wife, who works as a midwife, Mr. Young said he and Ms. Blount Moorhead decided they wanted the piece to “turn away from what had been done to our bodies and look closer at the rituals and music that help us get through trauma.”

Next month, visitors entering the gilt-ceiling chapel will encounter a quartet of screens playing clips of figures from jazz legend John Coltrane to harpist Brandee Younger to Nation of Islam leader Elijah Muhammad, who dispensed nutrition tips in his 1967 book, “How to Eat to Live.” The pair are still finalizing the montage but he said the environment will include elements of color therapy—anything to conjure “what healing looks and sounds like to me.”

Grief and cultural mending are familiar themes for Mr. Young, who spent much of his childhood in the Louisville funeral home owned by his grandparents, who hosted traveling jazz musicians who weren’t allowed to stay at local hotels. They also collected art by modern mainstays like Romare Bearden, Charles White and Aaron Douglas. As a boy, Mr. Young said, he spent hours leafing through his grandmother’s coffee-table books on Renaissance artists and black photographers. His early favorites included Gordon Parks and Roy DeCarava, who chronicled everyday black life in moody spotlight and shadow.

Photography led Mr. Young to study filmmaking at Howard University. In 2010 he wielded the camera for artist Leslie Hewitt’s ode to Harlem, “Untitled (Level),” a film installation later exhibited at the Contemporary Art Museum St. Louis. The collaborative experience was eye-opening, he said, because Ms. Hewitt “saw me as more than a cameraman; she saw a tension in my work I could unpack.”

The following year, he got his independent-film breakthrough with “Pariah,” a coming-of-age story about a black lesbian directed by Dee Rees, who would go on to write and direct “Mudbound.” Bigger films followed, including “Arrival,” for which he became the second black cinematographer nominated for an Oscar. (He lost to Linus Sandgren and “La La Land.”) Recently, he shot “Solo: A Star Wars Story.”

He met Ms. Blount Moorhead after she and curator Rashida Bumbray invited him to make a work for an exhibition that took place in several art spaces across Brooklyn in 2014: “Funk, God, Jazz and Medicine: Black Radical Brooklyn.”

He asked Ms. Blount Moorhead to join him in the “Back and Song” commission for Philadelphia. They have relished “excavating the margins of history” for footage, she said, adding, “We’re both intellectually thirsty.”

Write to Kelly Crow at kelly.crow@wsj.com
description: Bradford Young, the cinematographer of “Arrival” and “Solo: A Star Wars Story,” is preparing a multi-screen art installation that examines how black communities seek healing.
